Automark

Automark

Often, we bookmark pages that we want to be able to come back to or that we do not have time to fully digest at the moment. Just as often, we find our bookmarks to be cluttered, a mass of links that we know we want to visit. In this modern world where time is money and hundreds of websites are created every day, few take the time to organize and sort their bookmarks, which leads to even fewer users who will make use of their bookmarks at all.

Automark is here to change that. Automark is a bookmark manager Chrome Extension that uses Latent Symantic Indexing and Keyword Filtering to organize your bookmarks for you. With Automark, you can:

  • Organize bookmarks by automatically created folders
  • Search your bookmarks by keywords
  • Switch between folder generation algorithms
  • Sort your bookmarks by date
  • And more!

Technical Details

Automark first uses keyword filtering to extract the "gist" of a bookmarked website. When it enters your repository of bookmarks, Automark uses latent semantic indexing to generate a transformation matrix that transforms all bookmarked websites and keywords into a low dimensional vector that allows for faster searching among thousands of keywords. The folder generation uses a greedy algorithm to maximize the differences between folder names among your bookmarks to display them.

Built With

  • javascript
  • chrome
  • scss
  • numeric.js
  • numericjs
  • latent-semantic-indexing

Try it out

  • chrome.google.com

LumenSonics

Inspiration

Our professor is obsessed with the idea of a light-up princess wall, so we tried to make it come to life during Hackathon, equipping it with music-manipulation features to make it even more exciting.

How it works

We used Arduino to collect data from infrared sensors which were used to change the LEDs in brightness. We can also control music based on hand gestures over the light soundboard.

Challenges we ran into

  • Body temperature changes during different times of the day and thus the base value measured from IR sensors changes
  • Wiring the LED matrix to have constant luminescence and to prevent crossed wires from shorting out the circuit

Accomplishments that we're proud of

We were able to receive detailed and differentiated readings from each of the IR sensors, enabling us to incorporate music manipulation aspects into the project.

What we learned

  • Resourcefulness (e.g. our makeshift speaker system)
  • Everything is connected; changing one aspect may have unintended consequences on another.

What's next for LumenSonics

  • Add more music manipulation features
  • Make control more precise

Built With

  • arduino
  • leds
  • infrared-sensors

Momentmap

"Afoot and light-hearted I take to the open road. Healthy, free, the world before me."

Walt Whitman knew it well, that life was about that open road, but what he could not account for is the epic growth of technology. I do not view technology as not living in the "real" world, I see it as connecting with the real world in ways we never could before: technology is a complement to taking to the open road.

The inspiration for Momentmap stemmed from wanted to be connected to others, in person. I am also an inquisitive and often impatient person, this lead me to Momentmap because this app allows one to know how long it will take for his or her friend to show up. The user can see their location in real time.

The concept is simple: You send a message to your friend (photo, video, and/or text), select a length of time you want them to see it and send it their way. After the time you allowed is up, your photo, video, location and text all get deleted. The sharing of your location is only momentary.

I do understand that location based social media can be a privacy issue. But this app is a messaging app. A messaging app that allows people to share only what they want to for as long as they want to whomever and only whomever they want to. I am absolutely most proud of this feature because I believe this app will finally solve the issue of location based social media being "creepy". My app calculates the estimated time of arrival so if parents used this app with their children they would both feel safer while still being able to respect one another's privacy.

I believe it is important to not think of social networks as a place online but a place online that leads to have first hand experiences in real life.

  • xcode

Duncan Schertler

This was a project which I worked on for the Hack UVA hackathon. While it did not win a prize, it was accepted by many people as an entertaining utilization of various hardware.

The hack was a very simple application which was developed using the Unity 3d engine. While I borrowed a map and some scripting from previous hackers, there were several aspects which I added personally. The application used an Occulus Rift VR headset, and the Myo motion sensor. It allowed users to look and move about a three dimensional environment, with the VR headset and keyboard. Furthermore, the application contained a wand which the user moved, and aimed simply by moving their arm, and twisting their wrist with the help of the Myo. Additionally, users could flick their wrist (much as a powerful spellcaster might) and project a fireball from the tip of the wand which would knock over various objects in the environment.

I enjoyed working on this project, because I had the experience to work with technology which I had previously never experienced.

If you are interested in learning more about me, follow me on LinkedIn: http://www.linkedin.com/in/duncanschertler

wonder

The idea for this app comes from the movies "Shop Around the Corner" and "You've Got Mail," where two characters communicate anonymously, having serious conversations. Tinder is currently the most popular "dating" app out there, but it's superficial, and I doubt anybody's going to start a real relationship (friendship or otherwise) off of Tinder. Hence wonder was created, an app that provides the same appealing user interface and simple design of Tinder, but allows people to choose their matches based off of hobbies, interests, etc. instead of photos.

The user interface and overall design of the app are nowhere near final. A final version would be a bit more slick, like other social apps.

Here's how it works. You sign up and choose an Alias - the app uses no photos, no real names - from a list of names that have meanings associated with them. After putting in basic info like gender and age (you need to be 18 or older), you list hobbies, interests, favorite books, conversation topics, and so on. Finally, you put together a quick bio (no heavy personal info) focusing on the kind of person you're hoping to match with. You also choose a "spirit animal" which will act as your picture.

The app is location based, allowing you to choose where you search for people. This means you can possibly look for a foreign pen pal, if that's what you wanted.

Once your profile is set, you can look at conversations you're having with people or click the "wonder" button, which allows you to search for new people to talk to. The final version of the app would incorporate word clouds into people's profiles for a more appealing user interface.

Late in development, we decided to change the entire nature of the project. Inspired by the Crush pages that most universities have on Facebook, we decided to begin working on an app that allows users to send anonymous crushes and compliments to people. We are still working on this, but we are excited to see how it turns out.

Built With

  • java

Smasher

We introduce Smasher, the combination of web technologies to make your scheduling lives easier.

With Smasher, you don't have to worry about entering your calendar for each event/meeting you attend - rather, your calendar is simply reused to allow others to see a glimpse at your schedule, without invading your privacy.

Smasher is an all-in-one calendar tool, offering the ability to store your events on a reliable platform, while also assisting you to Smash schedules together - to find the free times you and your collaborators have.

Even if you don't want to use Smasher as your primary calendar tool, you can upload your calendar (in an .ics format) to our application, which will parse and populate your calendar for you.

Using our simple and intuitive interface, your scheduling woes are gone - no longer do you have to deal with the days of attempting to find meeting times - Smasher will do it for you!

HoopiOS

Our app was designed with the goal of curating the best social photographs in a users given geographical area. In our app, HoopiOS, users rate a photo unbiased by social media clout, personal relationships etc. by voting on the quality of instagram photos indexed solely by geographic location. Users will be able to view photos, the location where they were taken, and the photo's current score ("Re$pects" - "Disrespects"); users will also be able to view the top hoop photos in their area.

The intended audience of this app is social media and photography enthusiasts. By reaching a user base with an existing appetite for social photography via a simplistic interface, we believe that Hoop will bring great joy to its users.

The features that we are most proud of are our dynamic buttons, polling a wide audience based on the location of the user's phone, and community based ranking. We envision this app in the near term becoming not only a tool for users to learn about and enjoy the community around them, but also a novel form of social interaction that will reinvigorate a stagnating field. In the long term, we will consider implementing functionality allowing users to opt-in to displaying their instagram user data along with the photos pulled from the Instagram API. This would allow users to build their social media presence and find additional channels of exposure should they so desire.

GroceryReminder

Inspiration

Jennifer and I thought of making this app after we had attempted to make a more complicated one and decided that it was too much to tackle at our first hackathon. Neither of us had any prior experience in creating mobile apps of any sort, so it was a learning experience for the both of us.

How it works

GroceryReminder allows the user to type in the GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude) for his or her regularly visited grocery stores and make a list for each individual store. The lists made by the user are stored in the app for later access. Using the user's GPS location the app can compare the user's current location to the location of the stores saved in the app. If the user is near one of the stores, the app will remind the user with the list that was made for that specific store.

The app can also use the user's location to find stores nearby, that are not previously saved by the user. The app lists the stores close by and offers the option to save the locations of stores listed.

Challenges we ran into

Since we were relatively unfamiliar with how to use MIT App Inventor, we ran into several minor roadblocks along the way. Putting together the final product required hours of tedious programming and nit-picking (as do most hackathon projects...).

We were unable to find the stores using their street addresses, so the user must type in the GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude). Fortunately it is relatively simple to find the latitude an longitude of the store using GoogleMaps or the website http://www.gps-coordinates.net/ .

Accomplishments that we're proud of

Seeing as this was the first time we had ever made a mobile app, we are very proud of finally getting the design to work, and getting the app to properly function.

What we learned

We learned how to use MIT App Inventor to design a simple yet effective mobile app for android devices incorporating GPS and location devices and text to speech recognition.

It was really exciting to set our minds to something and watch it take shape on Jennifer's tablet and my phone.

What's next for GroceryReminder

GroceryReminder is in the rough cut stage of development with a few minor glitches. As we get a better understanding of mobile apps and programming we plan to improve its functionality and user friendliness.

  • gps
  • mit-app-inventor

EnRoute

What's a big problem when going on any long car ride? When can you get food or fill-up gas without going too far from your route! Current navigation apps do an inadequate job of providing options actually on the route, instead of merely in a circle around your current location. Similarly, if you want to grab lunch in an hour, you need to manually search the map, guessing where you'll wind up. EnRoute solves all of these issues in more in one elegant app for Android. Not only will you see food/gas options, and how long of a detour they are from your current route, but these solutions are sorted based on how long you can wait until needing to stop. This unique "patience meter" allows for a greater degree of user decision making. Just open the app, type in your destination, and go!

BAC Monitor

BAC Monitor is an app that addresses the problem of alcohol poisoning, sexual assault, and other alcohol-related issues by closely monitoring your intake levels and automatically reaching out for help when necessary via SMS. The app is able to detect when too much alcohol is consumed by calculating the users BAC. As the users BAC reaches higher levels, his or her friends are notified. By use of the accelerometer, it is able to detect when the user falls and alerts nearby friends of the incident. Further combining the accelerometer with the GPS functionality, the app is able to detect and automatically notify surrounding friends via SMS with the users BAC and location in the case that the user falls asleep or passes out away from home over a certain BAC level. It also keeps track of the users active and still time, as well as the total number of falls throughout the night. This app is mostly targeted towards college campuses. Recently there have been a lot of alcohol-related incidents that could have been easily avoidable. This app aims to greatly increase the safety of college students while allowing them to still have a good time.

  • android
  • java
  • android-studio
  • juno

WhiteSpace

WhiteSpace is a platform for human expression. WhiteSpace is a digital whiteboard available to the internet. Artists are queued to access an "idea space," a reduction of the total available area. Once queued, the image currently in the space can be modified by the Artist for 5 minutes. The tool available is a brush.

The idea behind WhiteSpace is the celebration of temporal existence: every 24 hours the entire space is cleared, there is no database to hold the images. The audience can view it on their monitors at

http://hopspot.me/whitespace/website.html

This gives the creations intrinsic value based on its future unavailability. There are no embedded links or images, all content must be created in the 5 minute span.

It's not beautiful or technically rigorous. It's spam. It's doodles. It's crude. It's honest.

WhiteSpace was made with scalability in mind. The demo displays a 4-idea space view (2x2). This could expand to 50x50 or 100x100 easily, given the relatively low demand for memory.

inforum

Inspiration

We wanted to find a simple way to create study groups quickly and efficiently without the hassle of asking everyone in your class (whether you know them or not).

How it works

For our mobile option the user starts by texting "Hello" to our service to begin the process. They are then asked for their subject of interest and zip code. They are then matched to people who are studying the same subject within their location. Everyone matched in the study group will be matched to a chat room where they can discuss how they can meet up to study.

On our website, we offer a way for people to sign up through Facebook and make study groups on the website. It offers a listing of all current study groups that are created.The website also includes a list of Facebook friends that are currently on the website looking for study groups. Once again, study groups are linked to a chat room where people can discuss how they want to study.

Challenges I ran into

We had initial problems with learning how to use the Twilio API; learning how to actually process and send SMS. Also, managing the different versions through git was another challenge that required some effort to remedy. The meteor framework, although very useful, is not a complete framework and required additional packages to supplement some features that weren't quite there. Finally, since we are developing a mobile and web-based service, we had to guarantee that the code would work for both computers and mobile devices.

Accomplishments that I'm proud of

Processing our first SMS after a long time of racking our brains together and googling was an amazing accomplishment. It felt as if our main task was achieved. The next great moment was when two of us were finally able to connect to each other and talk in a chat room.

What I learned

We learned how to utilize virtual boxes, ubuntu, git, and a bunch of other frameworks. Some of us were introduced to meteor and how amazing javascript can be.

What's next for inforum

What's next is a public release across college campuses (first UVA) to see how well the service works. Our future goals include being able to process human language better in determining subjects so that differently worded subjects that are the same are grouped together.
